  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10699189972/job/29660180078)

maintainer merge
maintainer merge
Is `iota` the standard name for this?
It's inspired by `List.iota`; that's the only reason.

@nomeata `iota`  actually produces numbers in _decreasing_ order. You are thinking about `List.range`.

It would be nice to generalise what should be called `LTSeries.range` to other starts, ends and even steps, based on either `List.range'` or `Finset.Icc`.

Oh, it does? Sorry for that, will fix.

As for the generalization - in my application I use `.map` to shift it around. But you are right, the generalization seem to add reasonable convenience.

Hmm,  not sure if `range (start := 0 : Nat) (end : Nat)` is nice; the length would be Nat subtraction, and having that in the types (`Fin (end-start+1)`) is probably not nice.

But this might be ok
```lean
/-- The strict series `start < â€¦ < start+n` in `â„•`. -/
def range (n : â„•) (start := 0) : LTSeries â„• where
  length := n
  toFun := fun i => start + i
  step i := Nat.lt_add_one _
```
updated the PR to this.

After updating my use of it I found that this generalization kills some somewhat useful defeqs (in paticular `(range n).last = n`), so reverted to not supporting a start different from 0, at least not until someone asks for it (and note that with `RelSeries.drop` one can easily construct the general version from simple building blocks).
I don't really care about generalising `LTSeries.range` to nonzero start points either.

```suggestion
  toFun := (â†‘)
  step i := Nat.lt_add_one i
```

```suggestion
/-- The strict series `0 < â€¦ < n` in `â„•`. -/
```
